data.text: The foot of an animal, especially a quadruped, that has claws or nails.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A human hand, especially a large clumsy one.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To feel or strike with the paw or paws.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To strike or scrape with a beating motion.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: The bull pawed the ground before charging.

data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To touch or handle clumsily or roughly.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To feel or touch (another) in an annoying or unwanted way. synonym: touch.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To scrape the ground with the forefeet.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: To handle someone or something clumsily, rudely, or with too much familiarity.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.
examples: Don't paw at everything you see.

data.text: The hand or foot of an animal which has nails or claws: distinguished from hoof: as, a monkey's paw; the paws of a cat, dog, rat, etc. In many animals the fore feet, and in some the hind feet, are prehensile, and serviceable as hands.
